0.text:
If you look at the history of the world, a
huge fraction of the improvements in the standard

4.text:
of living have come because private businesses
have created new products, have given people

9.text:
jobs, have generated profits that raise people
out of poverty and allow them to live fruitful

15.text:
and productive lives with reasonable standards
of living. We can have much more of that,

19.text:
and it will have beneficial effects around
the world, if we step back from the excessive

24.text:
regulation and have a much more capitalistic
system.

29.text:
My name is Jeff Miron, and I'm Director
of undergraduate studies in the Department

33.text:
of Economics at Harvard University. I want
to talk about three myths about capitalism.

37.text:
The first is that being pro-capitalism is
the same as being pro-business. Nothing could

42.text:
be farther from the truth. The point of capitalism
is to make sure that businesses have to compete

47.text:
vigorously against each other, and that benefits
consumers. It's not good for the businesses

53.text:
per se because they have to work really hard.
So many businesses understand this, and they

58.text:
hate capitalism. They're constantly trying
to get government to erect various rules,

62.text:
restrictions, regulations that help them,
but they're not in the interest of the consumers.

67.text:
So pro-capitalism is good for consumers. That's
who we're ultimately trying to help.

72.text:
A second myth is that capitalism generates
an unfair distribution of income. What true

77.text:
capitalism does is rewards people who are
productive; people who work a lot of hours,

82.text:
people who have a lot of talent, people who
come up with good ideas, they get big rewards

87.text:
under capitalism, and people who don't do
those sorts of things get less. The one negative

93.text:
one might be concerned about is that some
people have very little skill. They are not

97.text:
able to earn very much left on their own,
and so very reasonable people support some

102.text:
antipoverty spending. But that's completely
different than interfering with capitalism,

107.text:
regulating prices, limiting quantities, opposing
all sorts of things on businesses. Those make

112.text:
the economy less productive, give us a smaller
pie, and make it even harder for us to operate

117.text:
programs that help those who are less fortunate
and because they were unlucky.

123.text:
The third myth is that capitalism was responsible
for the recent financial crisis and the recession.

128.text:
That, again, is almost exactly the opposite
of what is true. First of all, nobody who's

135.text:
being intellectually honest thinks that we
had unbridled, serious capitalism before the

140.text:
crisis hit, before the subprime buildup occurred,
before we had all the housing problems. We

145.text:
had enormous government interventions that
subsidized risk, enormous government interventions

150.text:
that encouraged an over investment in housing.
If one's going to try to draw any conclusions,

154.text:
it seems to suggest much more clearly that
interfering with capitalism generates financial

159.text:
crises, generates recessions, because what
we experienced was directly related to the

164.text:
incentives for excessive risk taking, the
incentives for over investment of housing

168.text:
that were created by government. The private
sector responded to those incentives, so of

172.text:
course the private sector can't be completely
absolved of being involved. But in the sense

178.text:
of causing, it was the bad policies that caused
it not what the private sector or capitalism

183.text:
did on its own.
Most importantly, whenever government bailout

187.text:
people who took excessive risk, they encourage
people to do more of that in the future, and

192.text:
we unfortunately went a huge way in that direction
via the TARP and via all the federal reserve

197.text:
policies, which helped Wall Street and the
risk takers not have to pay the true price

203.text:
for all of the excessive risk taking they
engaged in.
